reviewText:
Hey, herostar here. Yes, herostar of alexina, the blue haired gun toting bard of spiral hill.

If you know me, then you already know this game is more worth your time, and perhaps a bit of your money, than I can ever recommend. I've played this game for almost 5 years now, my 3rd year milletian title proving this strong. I've collected pets, learned all the skills, met so many wonderful people, and even speak to the community manager through steam (I've got more hours on this game than Sabina, the dedication is Real.)

Regardless, I'm gonna give you my review of this game. Hold tight, we got a Lot of points to cover.

Let's start with the first impression. Mabinogi is not a hold-your-hand type of game, and you'll get little to no explanation on how things work. This led me to blunder around for nearly a year before I figured out how things worked, and yet, looking back, I still don't think it was a bad experience. The game holds true on it's free to play title, as you can go from 0 to 100% absolutely free. Pets and other things can even be earned in events, and just about every bit of clothing is sold on the market.

Combat. Well, it's certainly entertaining. From the unique rock-paper-scizzors approach to some moves, and just how well you can time moves against foes, it's possible to do an entire dungeon or mission without being hit once. The game's combat flows smoothly, giving you time to react to the challenge ahead, and prepare accordingly.

Classes: Let me get this out of the way real fast, you are not limited to one class in Any way, shape, or form. You can go from warrior, to mage, to archer, to bard, all in the same week. You can learn every single skill in the game (provided some exceptions with race and the like) all on one character. Infact, I have learned everything an elf can learn ingame!

Skills: Now this is a topic I love. First off, every skill is unique. Unique in animation, unique in execution, unique in effect, in damage, what effects it, every skill has it's own specialty to it. Each skill goes from Rank Novice, to Rank 1, minus some that have a rank limit due to there being no more content for that skill. (Yet*) And as an added bonus, the skills also can give, and often do, a variety of stats to increase the power of your character in many different categories.

Stats: Oh boy, these things... There are a total of 5 stats, being Strength, Intelligence, Will, Dexterity, and Luck. Each stat effects your skills and other aspects about your characters. Some stats even effect the chances in skills, such as Dexterity effecting Cooking. You can have Rank 1 skills, but if your stats are laking, there's nothing that'll save you from being underpowered. There's also of course, health, mana, defence, protection, magic defence, magic protection, and so many more, but these are all effected by the base 5, as well as certain skills.

Community: Sadly lacking. While there is a few good souls left, mabinogi's community has really fallen apart over the years... it makes me sad as a bard to see noone follows Bardic code of Conduct anymore, as simple as those rules are. A tip from a true erinn hero: If you have to mute your game for any reason whatsoever, there's a problem. And with important figures like Tanino being chased off from the game entirely, I truely fear for the worst...

Company: Nexon's not perfect, not by the longest shot possible, but it's not the worst. Nexon is doing what they can to keep the game bug free and happy, and you gotta give them credit for where credit is due. That's all I'll say about that, since the less said about their customer service ticket waits, the better.

*And finally the best perk: It's constantly being updated and added to. It's always changing, for better or for worse, and so far, I'm enjoying the content they've added. Talents like Ninja, gunslinger, fighter, puppetteer, even the massive list of bard's buffs weren't in the game when I started. But god, do I love that they came <3


Overall, mabinogi's a game I grew up with, it's a game that I love and respect like a brother, and even if it might see a downfall, it's still going down as a golden gem in my history books. Overall rating 9/10, I'd recommend this game to everyone who owns a computer.

reviewText:
This is a game where you feel immersed in its world. I have played countless of hours in the amazingly detailed world of Mabinogi. I have 300+ hours on Steam from when I wrote this review but I've played this game before it was even on steam, back in 2009. The world is vast and beautifully made. I have still not visited every destination and I have plans to in the future to do so. The community in this game is outstanding. Never played with such an amazing community. There are many items that you can purchase from other players with an in game economy. Or you can buy some with real money using a gachapon system (Kind of like the Team Fortress 2 crates without the keys). But you honestly don't have to buy any of those cosmetic items to enjoy the game. There are hardly any level up restrictions with no level cap. But levels don't really matter. Its all about the skills. Every time you level you gain a skill point that you can put into the many skills you will get to improve them. Rebirthing to make your level back at 1 is possible every 3 weeks if your character's age is 17. Thats my only problem. That it takes 3 weeks for you to rebirth unless you pay for a weekly rebirth. It is not needed because you will be spending those 3 weeks leveling you character like crazy if you're a beginner. Playing music with in-game instruments is an option using a music language known as MML (Music Macro Language). I would sometimes walk by an amazing composer with an amazing song or even bands that just play music for people's enjoyment. Mabinogi has a very strategic combat system with many different classes to play as. Nexon is constantly updating the game with in game events and even different storylines and generations(quest lines). You will not beat this game in a matter of weeks or maybe even months. I still haven't because of the quantity and quality of this product.

If you enjoy role playing games and MMO's you will enjoy this game. The community in this game is amazing and will make you keep coming back. This is a different kind of MMO. Its unique in its own way.
Server: Alexina
In Game Name: Cloudstride

reviewText: I joined Mabinogi back in 2009 and have loved it ever since. The difference with Mabinogi compared to most MMORPGS is that your character is you life. You dont have to follow the questline instead of fighting, why not cook or commerce? You want to fight using a sword while having a flamethrower strapped to your wrist? Go ahead. Mabinogi is a game where YOU'RE in control. Theres no level cap so you can keep playing and getting stronger and stronger. You even get benifits once your character reaches a cetain level. The story line is catching [Although text heavy] will leave you wanting more and more. The community is one of the best you'll ever meet, don't know what to do or where to go? Simply ask anyone and they'll help. Just play this game its hard to get into but once you understand it you'll have tons of fun with friends.

reviewText: im not very good at this review stuff so you can turn away from this comment now but all i can say is that Mabinogi is a great game, widespread adventuring space, and so much stuff do in the game but the only flaw is that its a bit too realistic and offers a bit too much. Theres not enough time to do everything but i actually like that. That feature could push or pull its community which is fine. If there was a perfect game i wouldnt be writing this. Also, most people i have noticed that quit the game are barely half way done. I still play (in fact for atleast the past 2-3 years my account has been made) and I still look like a noob.... sorta. Bottom line is, its a great game to just enjoy yourself and if your a SAO fan they just had or is having an event on that. The combat system is decent, all i can say is play this game if you want the closesest experience to SAO. If you've read this far, Congratulations your a patient person, a.k.a the possible player for Mabinogi.

reviewText: I've played Mabinogi since the introduction of G8, almost 8 years ago, more or less. Been a long time though. I don't play as much anymore. The hacking spree that occured several years ago has left the game in shambles and the pieces never get touched unless it effects the Korean servers. Like ♥♥♥♥ing hell, I log in today just to try to do a little fishing for the event, and I come into my homestead to find someone stealing from me, and everything is set to only be used by me but anyone can do anything with it. I'm so sick of everything being broken. I'm so sick of everyone treating me like ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ everytime I turn around and think everything's gonna be ♥♥♥♥ing hunky dory. This game should have had it's cable pulled in G14. End of story. Go play something else, kids.

reviewText:
Pros
-Unique Gameplay
-Nonlinear Progression
-Many different ways to spend one's time in game
-Average community

Cons
-Nexon
-Servers tend to be unstable at times. Makes certian skills & skill sets non-viable.
-PVP is fun, but has to be balanced by player-made rules.
-Many quests & events are incredibly vague. You must use the wiki for this game.
-Mainstream quest lines & lore are confusing as heck.
-Nexon continues to release more powerful cash shop itmes. You will likely spend at least the same amount of money you would on a subscription-based on them. If you're not a careful spender, possibly more.
-Client-sided lag even on the strongest of machines.

Variable (Depends on your personal tastes)
-Cell shaded anime-style graphics.
-Soundtrack
-Nearly infinite progression (Been playing for almost three years and I'm still nowhere near what I want.)
-Hilarious additions to the game that make no sense (Lightsabers, Guns, & Scooters in a medival fantasy-style world.)

One thing to note is that this game will probably ruin you for other MMOs, if you play it for too long. Point & Click will feel too dull, and anything strictly action based will feel awkward. I really wish there were more games like this, because Nexon & devCat don't seem to know how the heck to balance it.

reviewText: What can I say about this game? It's repetitive, boring, ugly, has a terrible community, and makes you feel like you're in purgatory. It's managed by Nexon, one of if not the absolute worst MMO conglomerates in the business. It's a time sink that leaves you sitting in town squares rather than fighting because fighting for more than an hour or two is an Olympic test of patience and fortitude. I have many hours on Steam, but I barely play it anymore. Before the Steam release, I sank 20,000-30,000 hours and upward of $300 in rebirths into a character, which got deleted by a hacker while I was taking a long break from the game. Did Nexon compensate me? No. Did they have so much as the decency to respond to my ticket? No. Seriously, why are you even looking at this game? Go play something good. Unfortunately I'm cursed by a history with this game, so I've yet to be able to fully shake it. People keep drawing me back in. Now I get why people keep playing ♥♥♥♥ like Runescape. Just get away while you can. I could've done so much more in life with the time I wasted on this unfulfilling, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

reviewText:
If my hours aren't enough, just try it yourself.
If you're gonna freak out over the graphics, go play something next gen instead of complaining about it.
Some general tips for starting out are:
This game is very different, keep an open mind.
The community is AMAZING.  The people are usually really nice compared to a lot of other MMO communities.
You ought to play on Alexina, just because that's where everybody is.
Don't blow all your money on it like I did, you can get along fine with paying absolutely nothing.
When you make your first character, you can select any option for the appearance, but only when you make your first character for the first time.
If you haven't tried it, I won't beg you to play it but I think you should.
You might like it.
You might not.
It'll be an experience.
Take it for what you will.

reviewText: One of my favorite MMORPG's. I would have to say I put a lot of hours into this game, just because there's so much to do. In the beginning, you can choose one of the many set classes in the game, which will end up being your main skill. But that isn't all you can do. Mabinogi doesn't just limit you to what kind of class you picked, and you can learn to be...let's say a martial artist, or  musician if you wanted to. It has a great combat system, because you have to plan what kind of attacks to use to counter your enemies. The feel of the game itself is very relaxing, and free. I would definately recommend this game to people who are into fantasy, and who need a game that has more of a free-roam feeling.

Just kidding. So yeah, this is a pretty interesting game with some cool mechanics, which sets it apart from other MMORPG's. I haven't played much, but I got some good first impressions. It isn't too heavy on required specs and should run fine on most PC's. The combat is very different, but execcuted well, in my opinion. There's plenty to do besides fighting, so this adds to the experience. I'd recommend this to any newcomers to MMO's or anyone that has been playing them for years. And it's free. So go do it. (This review was based around the time I last played, which was the summer of last year. Going to reinstall soon.)

reviewText: This game brings faith back to the Anime MMO genre. Usually you find games that play themselves by you just clicking a quest (*cough* aura kingdom *cough*) or Anime MMOs that have you picking one class and the skill/armors/weapons are extremely linear (*cough* Luna Online *cough*), However, this one throws all of those out the window. No equipment is unequippable" save for a few that require tons of training. None are just "better" than the others. The combat system is incredibly well-paced

reviewText:
I've got over 1000 hours on this game (not on Steam, but y'know), so I decided to finally write my review.
Well, to start off, Mabinogi is a great game. It's fun, addictive, and anime-styled. It plays well for the most part, save for some server lag in certain areas.
The other players are pretty friendly.
Mabinogi, in my opinion, is more fun playing with other people rather than on its own all the time.
Quests are optional, you're not forced to do them whenever.
There's lots of combat skills and then some life skills" which are non-combat like cooking

reviewText:
Mabinogi is one of my all-time favorite MMORPGs. If you spent countless hours playing RuneScape or Harvest Moon back in the day, you'll probably like this too.

Grinding by endlessly fighting monsters isn't necessary in this game, though the dungeons and fields offer the opportunity. Instead, much of your experience will come from quests and skill building. Part-time jobs offered by the shopkeepers of Erinn are a helpful way to gain exp, gold, and crafting supplies. Each character in this world is unique, so doing quests is a good way to build friendships.

There is a huge selection of skills, and you are free to build as many as you like. This includes, but is not limited to, fishing, cooking, tailoring, carpentry, metalworking, transformation, alchemy, music playing, swordfighting, archery, and magic. Practicing your trade(s) contributes to your skill level and your overall level. This allows you to use new techniques and recipes.

Your character ages at the rate of 1 year for every 1 real-life week. If your level and age get too high for your taste, you can be reborn as your younger self (or a completely new person with a purchasable character card). You keep your skills and items, but resetting your level allows you to try new quests and gain AP faster to promote skill growth. Your character grows and changes weight as you get older and vary your diet and activity, making rebirth all the more refreshing.

Overall, Mabinogi is a great MMO because it offers enough variety to last for countless hours of playtime. Even if the cutesy anime style graphics aren't to your taste, Mabinogi is worth a try if you long for a quality crafting/exploration MMO.

reviewText: Mabinogi is a Korean MMORPG brought over to the states (and other places) by Nexon. It provides a unique gamplay experience and is constantly adding new content. reviewText: Despite it's really outdated graphics, it remains my favourite MMORPGs of all time after over 5 years of playing. The seemingly endless amounts of content, good storyline, and attention to detail makes up for the lack of great graphics. There's also a good sense of a helpful community in the game that are often missing in MMOs that are lost in pure competitiveness. Mabinogi is one of the few MMOs that lets you take it easy when you feel like it; you aren't pressured to grind, you can focus on training more than one group of skills at a time, or just talk and have good times with friends.

reviewText:
Mabinogi is an intriguing game in some ways, and an extremely frustrating one in others. I'll break it down for simplicity's sake.

Pros:
- The graphics, while simple, are clean and polished. If you don't have contempt for anime styling, it looks pretty nice.
- The sheer variety of potential skills, combat-related and otherwise--it's extremely rare for a game to have its own music system, for example.
- The community is fairly friendly and welcoming.
- With the rebirth system, leveling is treated completely differently from most MMORPGs. It's still necessary, but more focused.
- Combat requires more input than clicking skills on a hotbar. You still do that, but timing matters and knowing the right time to play defensive is key.

Cons:
- There are very few enemy models, with constant recycled ones given a new coat of paint. This is to be expected in MMOs, but Mabinogi is hit extremely hard by it.
- The dungeons are likewise very formulaic, all series of hallways and square/rectangular rooms filled with enemies or incredibly simple puzzles.
- While the rebirth system takes some of the pain away from leveling, it still feels somewhat limiting. Initially, with the bonuses of a new character, you can rebirth and start from level one with skill levels intact every real-time day. Once these bonuses wear off, it's once a week. For some, this is fine. For me, it's tedious.
-Travel on foot is extremely slow. The game gives you the option of buying pets or using less feature-complete beginner pets to make up for this... Which is great, except it then puts pets on a timer. Once the time runs out, the pets go inactive until the next real-life day. It's needlessly limiting.
- While the rebirth system helps, leveling still slows substantially over time during the period between rebirths.

Don't get me wrong. I still like Mabinogi, and I still recommend checking it out... But you will know very quickly whether you have the patience for its unusual format.

reviewText:
My full review on Mabinogi.
I've gotten tired of playing several different MMOs.  But none of them I've played as long as I have played Mabinogi.  It rivals my playtime of minecraft- and I've played alot of minecraft.  Steam can only report about 25% of the hours I've played of it as most of the time, I had launched it through Mabinogi's website Located here.[mabinogi.nexon.net]

Mabinogi has gone through a management change within the last few years.  Before it was to the point where one could call it pay to play- as they had a subcription required at the time for priemium storage.  That feature is now open to all players for the next 83 years.

Many of the pet features that Mabinogi had used to be restricted to paying players.  Most pets were around 16 to 35$ USD.  The game itself is still pay to win, as the point of playing the game is to enhance the player's expirence of the game itself.  This game is not fully based on combat (though the Generation Quests say otherwise).

If you decide you want this game, it would be highly advisable to get yourself a human character to start with.  With the human character, you can get yourself a free Elf and Giant card.  Without paying further, you wont be able to get other cards.

Pets are still pay for- and they do provide a nice benifit aside from looking cute.  Some you can ride, some can also fly.  There are also pets that have a rather large inventory.  There are three current free pets.  Two you get from doing the basic quests (no added inventory) and one you get from the Saga questline.

The game is not a fair free to play.  You can get boosts of every description from the shop, and some of the shop outfits you cannot get via other means.  It is pay to win.

Though the free parts are rather nice.

Amount spent on this game: 45$

reviewText: It's a lot more in-depth than most popular mmos, surprisingly. There is a lot to do usually, but it sort of forces you to play alone most of the time unless you're doing an event or sitting around in a town and playing your lute while you talk about things with friends.\n\nReally, the only way you can enjoy this game is if you are baked out of your mind or are 12 years old with an extremely long attention span. It's fun, though, and there is a lot of customization available. Your character path isn't extremely limited to one class or playstyle, so you can pretty much just wander around and do whatever.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game can be pretty awful, but it can also be amazing. It's really one you just have to try out. High points are that it's very original and adorably quirky. The combat system pulls you in and can be deeply rewarding, but that same combat system will be one of your greatest drawbacks if you don't live near the server. If this is the case, a lot of time will be spent taking hits when your character is waiting for the server to respond to your commands, and in spite of this being an MMO, almost the entire storyline of the game forces you to play alone, which turns way too much play time into a lonely grind through waves of monsters who aren't hindered by server speed. The overt glitchiness is an early sign of how little support the game receives from its managing company, which is easily the root of its issues, but the community is awesome and the game really does play like nothing else out there. Definitely worth a shot. Don't pass it by if you haven't at least put a few hours in, because if it grabs you it grabs hard and you have a great time, but beware that you will deal with a lot of frustrating errors due to lack of support.

reviewText: Mabinogi is definitely one of the most interesting kinds of MMORPG's I've ever played. It's packed with things to do both combat and non combat related. The community is great depending on what server you're on (I'd suggest Alexina if you're a beginner) and is truly one of Nexon's crown jewels in the F2P Market that holds up with new content even after 6 YEARS. The style is friendly, warm and inviting. The music is also calm and relaxing in my oppinion. The skills are a point and click with a skill hot bar system which may turn off some people if they're tired of that kinda thing like I was, but the combat animation looks so cool I barely cared at all plus some skills require you to press buttons like the martial artist talent which I found pretty sweet. However I must explain the cons, The game's Rebirth System maybe confusing to some people. Basically it's the system that replaces traditional Level Up
date: Up a few of your skills". Mabinogi has a ranking system with each and every skill and you rank up these skills by spending a certain amount of "AP" which you get by Leveling Up and Doing quests that reward AP. So for those that feel at one point that they need to get more AP they're free to "Rebirth" which means resetting back to Level 1
recommended: BUT you keep all of your skill ranks so you're able to increase them further by leveling up. (NOTE: LEVEL UP YOUR WINDMILL SKILL FIRST
hoursPlayed: IT WILL BE MORE DIFFICULT TO LATER ON) Next on the Con List is the steam version..I've ran into so many problems with the steam version that I just up and decided to un-install everything and re-install it from the actual site. reviewText: Mabi's one of the few mmo's I keep going back to. Combat is not terribly complicated, but it beats standing in place and spamming abilities on a hotbar. There's also tons of stuff to do outside of combat now, and learning skills is easier than when it was first released in the states. The greatest flaw in this game is the cash shop, as it gives paying players a clear advantage in-game (for example, one can purchase pets/mounts that grant additional inventory space as well as items that reset points spent on skills).

reviewText:
Honestly this game, has changed a lot over the years... Some changes good and some pretty bad... ;;  If you've never tried Mabinogi befor, it's an interesting game to pick up and play with your friends. This game has a lot of story elements, that is tied with plenty of social interaction with other players. Once a huge hit when it was first released to English speaking shores, but now slowly dieing off into history.

The graphics are now dated, the engine... Surely, and the players of old have come and gone. The thought of a sequel or a spiritual successor is unknown to me. But if this game was rebooted, then it may have a brighter future. Sure there is Vindictus, aka Mabinogi Hero's". But it's not a Mabinogi where the cute graphical art style stood supreme and friends were your best and loyal comrades that help you out when you need them most. Not many games of today are focusing on R and R to just sit around a campfire and chat these days and tell stories...

Play this game if you're interested

reviewText:
The game is unique and addicting, and amazing when you have friends to play it with.

To get the best experience, i'd  advise you to wait until they have a special sale on pets, as having pets will increase your inventory space as well as  a means for faster travel.

Do not worry about competing with other players ; Set your own personal goals for the game.

There will come a point, however, where your character is so powerful that even the hardest difficulty is easy mode -  but you'll still find plenty of things to hold your interests.

My steam client for the game stopped working a year or so ago - right now i probably have nearly 3,000 hours put into the game if you combine the total play times.

reviewText:
I reviewed this game as not being 'My cup of tea' because it's best with friends, But then I tried playing it.
I was ushered into the game at first by a friend, And they kind of held my hand through the entire experience, So whenever I was left, I was clueless. I was wrong about it not being my cup of tea.
Think of it as a much more challenging and multiplayer harvest moon, but without the farming. The community is almost always fantastic, the non-combat skills are great, and the minigames are fun. At one point, in the game, I sat around a campfire with some fellow I'd just saved and cooked and then ate some bread, generously sharing some with him. When's the last time you can say you did something so tranquil in a game?

8/10 would reccomend, bit glitchy though, and the game is really confusing if you don't go with human. Also pay2win.

reviewText: This game is perhaps one of the strangest, most beautiful games that I have ever had the pleasure to play.\nI've had maybe 500 hours offline, and I'm still not even close to getting to the end of the game. Why not? Because you can have millions hours of this game, and you'll never finish. This isn't a game that's focused on fighting- it's shaped around social interactions. I've spent hours just sitting in a square, talking to friends and listening to people play music. This is a game that you'll go to find friends in, to relax and talk in, not fight endlessly in.

reviewText:
I used to like this game, and I occasionally spent a little money on it. It's one of those games where you have to put in a lot of time to get in any results, but I didn't mind. I had a lot of time to kill.

As time passed, it became increasingly clear that this was a pay-to-win, even moreso than in the past. The price of pets was rising to over twenty dollars. That was alright, I could still play. It wasn't as much fun, but I still had the friends I made in the universe of Mabi.

After a while, I started to have trouble launching the game - sometimes it would crash after a few minutes. Not long after, it started to do that every time I tried to play. I tried reinstalling it; at this point it quit launching altogether. I submitted a ticket to nexon, which was automatically canceled since it fell under Tech support; the automated message told me to post in the Tech support forums. I was a little irritated, but I did anyways. I had sunk a lot of time into this, so I didn't want to give up so easily. I didn't get any help, just a few useless comments and one or two people saying they had the same problem.

I found the game was on steam, and all was well for a time. However, when I helped my Guild mine stones for a castle we'd won in an Auction (it would only be ours temporarily) and we completed it, I found that I needed Premium service to actually enter the dang place. I was less than pleased. I still played a little, just dinking around and talking to my friends now and then, working an undeveloped character I happened to have when I had some time to kill. (I avoided playing it unless I KNEW I had a lot of time; many of the quests require a maddening amount of running back and forth to two NPC's who were often on different ends of the continent, or at least a few cities apart. This game is impossible unless you drop some cash on pets to get around without going insane. Even then, travel takes longer than is fair, and with the increasing size of cities, much of which are empty and with a handful of NPC's spread over something that can take half an hour or more to traverse on foot...) Then, after a while, it started crashing after a few minutes again. At this point, I begrudingly cut my losses, deciding that it wasn't worth the effort and the frustration I was getting from the worsening pay-to-win environment and rising costs.

reviewText:
Let me explain why Nexon is a ♥♥♥♥ company at handling their staff members.
I am only going to state FACTS, none of them are made up or conspiracy.


About Me & Mabinogi
I've started the game when it came out in Korea.
That was approximately 12 years ago.
I've played for about 5 years, then got hacked and my account got deleted.
So I quit the game, and joined Mabinogi NA about 1 and a half year ago.

My IGN is Rixx and I reside in server Alexina.
I've helped noob part of the community and angered a lot of greedy, rich players.
I've spent over $10,000 USD on Nexon over the last 4 years, I can say I'm a hardcore player.

I've been a Mabinogi modder for a long time, and I wouldn't deny that I distributed mods.
(All non-game breaking, making simple tasks easier such as enabling hotkey of an item, etc.)
Eventually Nexon got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ somehow and banned me.
Okay, I'm fine with that. They banned me for something I shouldn't have done.
I deserved it.


The GMs Think They're Gods.
Then when I got unbanned, I stopped making and distributing mods entirely.
It seemed all well, then I wake up in the morning and I see that my account has been banned AGAIN.
I sent a ticket to Nexon, and in the meantime I go through the live chat and ask for the reason why I'm banned.
The GM says he doesn't know, so I just waited patiently for a reply on the ticket.

After 3 days or so, some other GM says I'm involved in distribution of mods again.
What? I haven't even made any mods since last ban, so why are they banning me now?

I asked for evidences, evidences that wouldn't exist because I didn't do ♥♥♥♥!
And the GM just says the status on your account wouldn't let me unban you" or some crap.

I've talked to several people and found out that there's a private Skype chat between the GMs and some players
date:
and one of those players' hobby is to ask GMs to ban players he doesn't like.
Sadly I was one of those players who caught the attention of this abuser.

What's more is that the GMs set up a group called New Player Ambassador and enlisted these privileged abusers join the group to receive items that are not available in the game by any means.


Conclusion
I'm not even going to seriously try to get unbanned
recommended: because I know these money hungry pigs will simply let me blow more cash on the game and ban me for fun.\nMy point is
hoursPlayed: their staff members are corrupt and have no standards when it comes to dealing with players.\nThe game itself is great

reviewText:
With my previous experience with this game (and my current play after recent updates), it is hard to say whether or not I actually enjoyed it. What I liked was the customisability and open world feel to the game, with many different play options to explore.
However, after my terrible experience with paywalls a few years ago, I subsequently quit playing. Downloading it again to see what improvements had been made.
PROS
- The game is up to you how to play and explore.
- There are many different ways to customise your character.
- A devoted fanbase.
- Opportunity to waste many hours.

CONS
- Compatibility and anti-aliasing issues.
- It's an old game, so some textures look very low-res, whilst newer items/areas look far more detailed, which breaks the flow of the game, in my opinion.
- While the fanbase is devoted, the player base is much smaller than it was, leading to the world feeling barren and empty.
- The combat system takes a lot of getting used to, and often made me want to flip the table.
- Some story aspects seem forced to add content (race war, really?)
- Pop up windows, annoying and always at the worst times.

Overall, if you're new, you're a bit late to the party. Has Nexon quality (generally p2p and such). But if you can cope with the cons and somewhat annoying pop up windows, and playing mostly alone, then go for it!

[this review is my experience and opinion, debate it any way you see fit :)]

reviewText:
Stay away from it while you can.

~Axelrod of Alexina

If you want an explanation, literally all of the hours that I've put into this game have gone into AFKing. If there was a point where I wasn't AFK, it was because I was talking to friends. Why nothing else?

Your input is delayed if you don't adjust your network settings, the game's so unoptimized that the font they use is even capable of causing frame skips, and any new content they have have gets stuffed into a gachapon.

What's a gachapon?

A gachapon is a form of gambling that is legal for people of any age if you do it in Mabinogi, as long as you convert your real money into a fake currency they call NX and spend your NX on these boxes that are more likely to have garbage inside of them than what's advertised. And the people who localize this game even embrace gachapons enough to make them into a Steam emoticon.

So I'll re-emphasize my point. Stay away from this game while you can. This review update was brought to you by a bored Axelrod on 3/28/2016.

there are reports of players requesting aid in recovering stuff that falls through the cracks and waiting for somtimes years before a responce which never is an offer for help but may instead include a threat for banning or prossecution in court... most of the time it's an automatted message saying they dropped your ticket with no option to appeal... so dont bother customer service they are a bunch of meanyheads. Nexon doesnt do customer service... the page is there only for show.

I would have to not reccomend playing this game only because its run and managed by Nexon a very terrible game develloper/producer that has a tendancy to destroy wonderful creations and has an almost blantant disregard if not hatred of American & European customers. the game itself and its vibrant and adorible community are wonderful however.

if you plan on spending money on the game, make your purchases through Steam... as there isnt a limit to what or how much you want to spend... and Valve will butcher Nexon if they rob you. which Nexon has done in the past with thier game cards and homepage credit purchases.

mabinogi is adorible & fun... but my personnal experience with Nexon has ruined any chance ill ever play any of thier titles for risk of loosing an eye or limb.

reviewText:
Let me get this straight off the bat: I love Mabinogi. Character customization skill-wise is my top priority when it comes to MMORPGs, but when you start shifting the focus towards vanity items that do absolutely nothing except for making your character look good and you add a crap ton of random classes that confuse the heck out of enemy AI who've only had to deal with melee, bows, and magic, that's when I start frowning on the game. Ignore the playtime Steam has. I've played for quite awhile on the standalone launcher. Anyway, back to the review. In a nutshell, Nexon has turned Mabinogi into a cash grab with no good updates in who knows how long just to satisfy their greed. Yes, I just called Nexon out for being greedy. Yes, I will continue to point out Nexon's flaws through out this review.

| Gameplay |

The original system for Mabi's combat was a modified rock-paper-scissors match which required skill more than luck. Smash broke through Block, Counter evaded Smash's slow attack, normal melee couldn't break Block, etcetera, but with the addition of new classes and skills along with it, the AI of the mobs just can't cope. They only know the bare essentials with maybe a special skill or two for the bosses.
Outside of combat the economy of Mabi is jacked. You can hardly get started nowadays without buying something with real money from the Nexon store. Maybe, just maybe, if you find a experianced player then maybe they'll give you some gear, but with Mabi's playerbase dropping, it would be very rare.

| Graphics |

Perhaps the greatest point of Mabi is the graphics. But even then they look a tad outdated. Anime/Manga styled characters and mobs is the core concept of Mabi's graphics. Beutiful landscapes and sunsets, dark and grim dungeons, it is pretty cool, but still, it all could use a good polish.

| Community |

The second most important thing to me is the community of the game. Friendly players willing to help out the newbies, a good rivalry between guilds, the lightest touch of drama here and there... Mabi used to have all this, but with the player base dwindling, well, it's going to be hard to find a person and not a bot. And a reason behind it all is Nexon's inability to respond to support tickets.

| Summary |

Gameplay   - 3/10
Graphics     - 8/10
Community - 3/10
Average - 4.5/10

Mabi was fun. I loved this game entirely. Now it's just a shadow of a shell of its formor(reference) self.

reviewText:
Unlike other Asian MMOs where it is filled with fanbase of big boobs, panty shots, etc. for the male/lesbian taste, and mainly focused on combat. This is a fun MMORPG to try out for at least 3 days (or your money back).

When you first start, you may feel overwhelmed and excited to try out as many skills as you can. It is highly recommended that you try out each skill at least a few times before leveling it from Novic to F (if it requires 0 AP then go ahead) because you will not get those back. Eventually you'll figure out which talent you want to invest in, take your time on that.

One thing I really like is that the clothing/equipment doesn’t always look the same in color and may not have the same stats either, if created by tailoring and/or blacksmithing, same for some weapons. This game really focuses on teamwork and is very welcoming to casual players as well. Another thing I really enjoy the most is how some of the NPC's break the 4th wall at times, or that some of the enemy's you meet will wear funny disguises. Lastely, weapons and equipment are sort of irrelevant in damage and defense. Talents are what really helps you grow whether be combat or non-combat talents. Level, Age, and Race also play as a factor for stat increase. Can also earn money not only by questing or grinding, but by part-time jobs or commerce as well! If you play your cards right, you could earn 10k+ in no time!

There are a few flaws/annoyances though: Can only make one character (Only bright side is that with your first character you can pick all the choices, normal and premium, for customizing, however will have to purchase another character card via cash shop, depending on type price varies, or make an alliance with either Elves or Giants to get a free card of that race). There is no advance warning that you’re using a beginner inventory package till level 30, where you’re able to use the full bank inventory, but the right half will be locked after level 30 and anything stored in there will be stuck unless you get the Inventory Plus Service from the Cash Shop for $8 for 30 days. The inventory on your character may get easily filled if you’re taking on too many talents. When buying a pattern or a blueprint for crafting clothe, weapon, armor, you don’t know what materials will be needed till after you purchase and start to use it. Best to use the wiki for this, it’ll save you up on gold.

Recommend doing 2-3 life skill talents that require frequent inventory space like Tailoring, Medicine, and Cooking. It is nice to have at least one combat talent too like Close Combat (aka Warrior), Lance, Magic, etc. Say no more than two combat talents though if you wish to do any non-combat talents, and vise versa.

On the server I go to, Alexina, the community is friendly and helpful to newbies (however there are exceptions.) I have rarely seen any players that gloat/brag/show off about their W/L record, about how strong they are, or about their equipment and skills. This makes the game fun and comfortable to play in. Overall, who needs skill when you can have fun? That’s what the game is really emphasizing, fun!

The only piece of fanbase you’ll get the best of is at the start after making your first character. Enjoy the bouncy boobs while you can, because that’ll probably be the only time you’ll get to see anything jiggle on a woman!

reviewText:
Personally, I do not like Mabinogi.  It has a lot of promise buried some where deep within it, but it never really appears.

The story you experience in the game consistently has you helping NPCs you'd rather brutally murder.  And the quests tied to these stories have various levels of imbalance, either being way too easy for a long time, or way too cheap all of a sudden causing you to die like crazy.

Although the game gives an impression that you can choose what skills you want to learn, what race you want to be, what equipment you want to wear, and what you want to do, you quickly learn that, in order to be good at the game, these choices quickly stop being choices.  Due to Combat Power requirements that only get worse as you level up and learn skills, you practically have to learn the skills in a set manner, with the most gruelling and reviled of these coming first simply because your lower Combat Power makes them easier".  The races are imbalanced

reviewText:
Ground rules:
Don't ever jump into this game without knowing anything.
Don't recommend anything aside from a warrior talent for begginers. (Because no one gets other talent tutorials. You can always rebirth later anyway.)
Try to figure out a skill build for your current talent.
Experienced players are your best firends. (But don't make them your weapons.)
Sometimes the wiki is necessary.

Got it? Good.

Ok, now this game is meant for all of you who are sick and tired of MMOs with the WoW style targeting based combat system. Level grinding also isn't that important. What is important is your skills. Skills make up your stats, what weapons you use, and how you fight. Combat isn't meant to be a stat battle either, (although it certainly can be at times). What is more important is if you know how to use your skills, weapons, and the enemy's AI to your advantage. Overall you have to learn a few things by yourself in this game and not give up if you want to get anywhere.

reviewText:
Played it from the standalone version when it came out a couple years ago, had a lot of fun. The players were progressing a bit faster than the updates were coming, but everyone was fine with it, we were patient because the game was so solid and entertaining that being patient was the only logical thing to do.

I had an archer with a sword. I would shoot my most damaging skill while the mobs were far, knock them down when they got too close, then finished with 1 or 2 well timed sword skills.

The storylines were nice, the dungeons were even nicer, especially with friends.

The loot/equipment was such a joy to acquire, the hoods, the armor!

The classes worked so very good, it really was different from the rest.

STOPPED FOR A COUPLE OF YEARS

Came back around last summer to immerse myself in it again, hoping to catch a glimpse of what it used to be, maybe play a whole week non-stop during my holiday.

NOPE

Classes are ruined, system is chaotic, you don't work for what you want anymore, there's just too much stuff in your face distracting you from playing the game, the fighting is nowhere as good as it used to be.

There's just no adventure anymore, this game used to be about adventure.

reviewText: This is a fun game. The combat is satisfying, the side quests are amusing, the story is pretty interesting, all in all, it's a pretty good game. EXCEPT for the fact that it is poorly optimized. Not just I, but many others have reported crashing and freezing. I crash at Fiodh's Dungeon boss and I need to beat that boss to progress the story. But I can't! I've even paid money on this game and the fact I can no longer progress is quite frankly, fustrating. Perhaps you'll be luckier than me, but I would not take my chances with this game. It's a good one. But the fact that not everyone can continue progressing is a turn off to me.

reviewText: Having suddenly been re-engulfed in this game to a greater extent than ever, I'll try to give better context to its staying power. Mabinogi is very rough around the edges, thanks in part to the localization being managed by Nexon of all things. It's over a decade old and much a product of its time, unoptimized, laggy, hard to get running on a modern OS, not very user friendly, the game does not explain itself well, you will constantly have to reference the wiki to make any headway in a number of things and understand the convoluted backend systems at work, Nexon support is nonexistent, and above all else the barrier to entry is horrible.\n\nThe way character progression works is by leveling up to gain AP"

reviewText:
While this game offers something new and different than your usual MMO, it is unfortunately crippled by many issues. Nexon is an inept company that always fails to get it right the first time. Nexon's first and foremost concern is taking your money. Anything useful, conveient, and in some cases, necessary you will have to pay for. Nexon's customer service is abysmal; commonly taking them over a year to respond to ticket and even longer to actually resolve it, if that ever manages to happen.

Servers regularly crash and/or are under maintenance usually for a long time, especially during or after an update in which they inevitably break something. If they aren't, they're usually lagging, sometimes pretty bad. Hell, initally you need to mod the game just to make it acceptable to play.

If you do decide to play this game be prepared for attention ♥♥♥♥♥s, severe weeaboos, 12 year old girls, 13 year old boys, adults that act like 12 year old girls and/or 13 year old boys, meme spewing, and rampant hacking. I say more power to them (hackers). There needs to be people that can remind everyone about how bad Nexon sucks with this game.

A good game for people with a whole lot of disposible income ( or stealing mommy and daddy's credit card until they notice $100 vanishing every month) and people who can't play anything better.

Some pros for those that think (and will probably continue to do so anyway) that I'm being biased:
- Very moddable, pretty much everything, from the sun to the UI to the music can be modded into whatever you can find/make.
- A good break-away from your typical mmo; offering things other games could learn from.
- Interesting battle system. Although with a past update, took a bad turn imo.
- Expansive customization from characters to clothes (be prepared to pay for this too though)

Check out the forums.

reviewText:
(This is not a recommendation. It is an ANTI-Recommendation)

The game is Okay and all, but Nexon is crap. they are a horrible publisher, and choose to charge insane amounts for things that shouldn't be that high price. What's more is, if you try to get the BBB involved with trying to get your support ticket noticed (Mabinogi tickets have a 6+ Month waiting time at least) the BBB will tell you that Nexon America has opted out of BBB, and therefore support cannot be given via BBB. (Shows how much they care for customers, etc.)

The content updates are quite lacking nowadays, running out of ideas, still trying to milk money out of Mabinogi players, until Mabinogi 2 comes along (No, it's not Vindictus, there WILL be a Mabinogi 2.) Then they will just delete everyone, no refunds, no nothing, clean slate on Mabinogi 2.

Of course, this doesn't come without issues. Nexon KR, the parent company of Nexon USA, has always disliked their USA Nexon branch, and maybe won't even push Mabinogi 2 through to it. So in all, if you play anything from Nexon, you're better off just quitting, or following the crowd like sheep or lemmings. I'm not trying to be rude here, but because of Nexon's inability to Play Nice" with its community

reviewText:
I tried to like this game, I really did. I was first introduced to the concept of this game, by a fellow student in a Irish folklore and folk life class and it seemed to me to be everything I was looking for in an MMO when it came to lore and interesting mechanics, however that sadly did not turn out to be the case.

This game is defiantly for those who like to explore and have little to no guidance in what choices they make, which for me sadly meant wondering around a lot, losing time trying to figure what I was doing with my character, class and abilities and what have you. Between an almost dead community presences online (at least when it comes to help guide) and just overall becoming boring after the first few hours, Mabinogi just was not the right game for me
voteText: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It was hard to get into the character, not knowing anything about the game and just being tossed into the world with barely any knowledge of ... well anything.

Character cards are ridiculous and make no sense.  Allowing a person to make one character per account or card is just silly and was a big turn off at the beginning.  Then suddenly I'ma  horse running around attacking spiders and wolves but unable to talk to anyone and no idea what was going on.  It's basically a game for older players.  As in, people who have been playing it for a couple of years and have gotten to know one another rather well through the game itself.  Which is fine, if you're looking for a social game.  I was looking for something with more adventure.  This was not that game for me.

Although it does have combat, it's tedious and slow.  With numerous combat progamming issues such as slow to no response, it get boring and annoying very quickly.  If you want to be with your friends from the beginning you have to make the same type of character.  Unless you are one of the players who has played for some time then you're aware of how to get where and what exactly you're doing.

I was enticed by the farming, cooking, trade skill aspects only to learn that those are the main skills you pick from the beginning.  While you're welcome to learn other skills or professions, if you picked cooking then cooking would be the only thing you truly excelled at which gives the game another annoyance factor for me personally.

I'm not going to say anything about the graphics because I believe that graphics do not make the game no matter how beautiful or up to date it is, if the game play is awful it is awful and god rays won't save it.  t's dated to be sure but it works for what (I assume) the game is going for.  After awhile I got tired of children players running around and elves with large breasts giggling constantly and decided to try something else.

It's a charming thought but all in all this game left me more confused than with the feeling of enjoying a real role playing game.  If you have extensive amounts of time on your hands, do not like social interractions in the real world or are one of the few serious fans left of the game, enjoy.  Otherwise, I would try something else with better, more responsive controls and doesn't rely on extreme amounts of beauty shop items in order to enjoy the game"."

reviewText: For the 32 or so hours it took to download and install this game, it was not worth it. I feel like there should have been more of a tutorial for the game as I had no idea what I was doing. I felt lost, and the character customization was lack-lustre. I expected more options than what was offered to me. A lot of the hair and eye colours and styles were locked until you purchased something. I was also disappointed in the fact that you could not choose your own clothing at the start of the game. This is definitely a game in which you'd want to level up in, and I'm assuming that leveling up in this game takes a long time. However, I will say one thing: the online community present in this game is very helpful and friendly. They were willing to give me and my friend really nice new clothing when we accidentally sold ours and were quick to offer tips and advice on playing this game. My only advice to you is that if you're interested in playing this game, doing extensive online research on how to play the game before playing would be highly reccomended in order for you to have a good start. However keep in mind that my friend and I did a little research; including watching a few Let's play" videos on youtube

Sadly I wasnt able to get over the other issues.

reviewText:
This game rings back so many memories, as if I was still a young boy again, this was something extraordinary. I played more or less for the first 3 yrs of the popularity of the game.
I have countless hours, day and night put into this game, but unfortunately the game updates so quickerly, lurcking you to rebirth over and over to keep the speed up, then this game starts to sink, and that's most of my frds quit this game. and there goes me. and at that time 700+ lvls was decently high. and wasn't full time gaming like some others.

that was 5-6 yrs ago, now It's a bit harsh to go back, but just to remember its moments, but there's nothing to go back anymore, unfortunately.Everyone drifted, I missed this game. I missed those frds. and fortunate for me. I had a great time playing this game.

reviewText: I tried my hardest to enjoy the game, but the combat was just terrible and there were way, way too many bugs for a game as old as this (If you're wondering it was released in 2004 in korea and 2008 in NA). There were just so many times where I would enter a building and get stuck and have to relog or be fighting an enemy and your character will literally just sit there. With that being said, this MMO is more of a social game rather than a combat game, which isnt really my cup of tea. The graphics are nice but they definitely haven't aged well at all. I think the biggest flaw though is the somewhat Pay-to-win aspect of the game. You almost HAVE to spend a decent amount of money to even make the game convient enough to play. They give you a mount to use, but even then it only lasts for 1 hour and a half each day unless you buy the permenant" version
date: and in a game where the quest NPCs are sometimes continents away
recommended: you'll find yourself spending more time walking from place to place than actually enjoying yourself."

reviewText:
This game is more than just a bad game or a game with too many nerfs, buffs, ecenomic instability, pay to win or anything like that.... all of those are here in one way or another but hear me out, please:
Mabinogi is the definition of the game that punishes you for playing it.

First off, if you do have a morbid curiosity and decide to start the game, mute it. Immediately. Go into your control panel, turn down the Client.exe or Mabinogi volume through system settings, then play. If you do not do this you will be blasted with late-90's synth music that will at least make you ill, and the remaining sound effects will make you deaf.
If you are still playing you will notice that you have nothing to do, and no idea what to do at all. While odds are you won't need the wiki at this point, you will need to do anywhere from 20 to 30 missions depending on the class you picked just to unlock your skills.
If you manage to actually do all of these 15 minute long missions for each skill, you should just stop. Close the client, because  what you did was all you should do.

You see, the game developers (at least for the north American side of the game) don't actually like it when people play the game, because their special events" give you more experience for doing half-programed mini-games than actual dungeon crawling
date: which no one does because dungeon crawling is obsolete
recommended: and has been for years. How? simple: buying "gachapins" from the real-money shop can give items that are better than anything you will ever find in any dungeon. What about making the armor with blacksmiths? NOPE: event and gachapin items have better stats than anything a blacksmith can make. The newest lifeskills even? nope
hoursPlayed: new armor an weapons where released a few months later. Anything that doesn't involve throwing away real money and standing around doing nothing will just make you a second-rate character
voteText: and sometimes
helpfulPercent: you just have to sit around and do nothing
votesHelpful: since most events reward you if you're AFK!\n\nThe only thing that 90% of people do in this game is sit around town in their outfits
votesTotal: or try to make money by doing event mini games to make money. The few people who actually play the game typically hate what the game has become
votesFunny: and would play something else if they hadn't invested so much time and money in the game.\n\nOh
commentsCount: did I mention that the story will make your eyes bleed? Don't read the fluff text
column16: especially if it involves Shakespeare.\n\nTL;DR: doing nothing in this game is more rewarding than actually playing it. Do not waste your time and sanity."

reviewText:
A good MMO if you don't want do battle. The battle system sucks and is frustrating as hell, however the music system is original and good, it allows you to put any song you want into the game, if you know how.
On the music system there is a lot to offer, ranging from different instruments to creating your own music score, solo or band optimized.
The music system is the largest pull of the game, and is certainly what got me to get the game and stay in it for longer than I care to admit.

Be wary of the free" grab as well

reviewText: I Have been playing Mabinogi ever since it came out. This game really is spectacular. It takes getting used to, but there is SO MUCH TO DO. You are not limited to fighting in this game, you are not restricted to one class. If you want to be an archer-warrior-mage-musician, then go for it. Mabinogi is by far the ultimate MMO. It is NOT pay to win in the slightest. Which is why it is the only mmo I can play. It is not grind heavy either like most MMO's. The anime aesthetic is very nice as well. If you haven't tried this game, I highly recommend doing so. Avoid Mari and Tarlach servers.

reviewText: Obvious flaws this game has include a very non-standard control scheme that takes a good bit of getting used to, a large amount of exploitable cash shop items, preiods of long grinding that occasionally become necessary, the worst customer support I think I have ever seen in my life, and a community filled to the brim with elitest ♥♥♥♥♥♥ with little or no interest in helping new players adjust and progress at all and a pretty limited endgame. (if you can ever get there)\n\nOverall, however, dispite all its grevious shortcomings, Mabinogi is an amazing game. It has a massive pool of content and the options for character customization are as close to literally endless as I have ever seen in any game before short of going old school and playing D&D or some third party variant thereof. Something that I tend to use as a selling point is the games lack of a level cap. Basicly how it works is leveling up gets you ap, ap gets you skill ranks, skill ranks give you permanent stat boosts. Once per week you can rebirth, which resets your level to 1 but lets you keep all skills you ranked and all the stats they gave you. The game keeps track of your total level"

reviewText:
An MMO that falls just short of perfect, it has basically everything you would want in an MMO:
-free form character creation that lets you constantly build your character's strength, forever
-a wide array of awesome to goofy mounts
-a pretty large open world
-a complex crafting system that provides useful items
-player homesteads where you can craft, farm, decorate, etc
-a long and constantly added to story broken up into arcs that can actually be surprisingly well written
-constant updates that add very significant features
-frequent events that can be pretty fun
-many different ways to play, and fun minigames to play, some for daily bonuses (ie - rafting, alone or with friends try to steer a raft down a river and used ranged abilities to kill goblins on the shores attacking you with magic and arrows, some melee ones will jump onto the raft and attack as well!)

but there's some downsides that you should consider before you get into it:
-pets and mounts cost money, although they do give you some basic ones for free now. limited edition ones can be powerful and extremely useful for certain kinds of crafting and playstyles so it's hard not having them sometimes
-the combat is based on manipulating skills to counter the enemies and when you start it'll be hard to figure out what enemies are good to fight despite a combat power" system that's supposed to help
date: it's not really accurate\n-it takes a loooong time to build up a decent amount of power
recommended: and if you start with magic good luck with that
hoursPlayed: some of the spells can literally take you years to get if you're trying to get them alone because you need extremely rare drops from hard dungeons\n-the game can be extremely confusing at first because almost nothing is explained well
voteText: they've started adding more in-depth tutorials but you'll still have a hard time figuring out what to do as a newbie\n-some people will be seriously turned off by the goofy cell shaded anime art style
helpfulPercent: but the screenshots are on the store page so you can see that for yourself. It can be seriously worth a laugh though when you see something like the pelican pet's running animations\n\nin the end though the game's sheer volume of content that's surprisingly high quality overpowers the downsides so once you get into it the game's very good for being mostly free. I've played it since it came out in 2006 and I've probably spent $60 tops on it
votesHelpful: and most of that was not needed to be competitive in gameplay."

reviewText: Hardly find any MMOs that are worth some time and effort. This is one of those few. The fact that there are a large number of people playing this, some friendly, others that troll, as well as a unique skill upgrade system that doesn't cost any in game money (Save for a few), it's not a matter of what can you do next, it's a question of what WILL you do next. For all intents and purposes, this is what ESO should've been, and this was out years before any trailers for ESO... or Skyrim. However, the downside is to how dull things can seem to get, especially with repetitive gameplay. So, this gets a 4/5 for showing a unique side to MMOs, as well as having a multi-sided theme.

reviewText: The only MMO that I've ever spent more than three hours in. Going into everything I think about this game would literally be super freaking long, so I'll make it simple. Technical wise, this game is crap. But everything else is great: A player community full of people who are usually very nice, MANY classes that you can choose, and a rediculous amount of quests. Completing all 19 of the main storylines is quite the feat, and even after having played this game for 400+ hours, I still haven't done so. Just be prepared for the game to not work at all when you first install it. If that DOES happen to you, either you'll just have to go do something else, or a LOT of troubleshooting.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Very good MMO Experience!

Mabinogi has many features, the possibilities to what you can do are endless and the skills amount to that similar to runescape. Theres even a skill for egg gathering! You can honestly do anything on this game, tame a random mob, turn into a butterfly or raid the biggest dungeons.

The combat is fun, with VERY cool looking animations, there is a wide variety of mobs for you to fight and gear isn't hard to get.

It is not pay to win at all, the only thing you can pay for is Pon, which only makes your character look cool and occasionally it gives you that for free. Premium outfits are usually sold at the Dunbarton market for gold, and there are various, easy methods to get gold.

Once you get bored of combat in general, you can devote your life to adventuring, or cooking, maybe even a grocery store clerk? This game can't really get too boring unless you hate life in general.

The only downside to this game is that the movement gets glitchy once in a while and some of the animations seem to skip frames, either than that, very good play. (Also graphics are okay, but they are anime styled and wont be super good)

reviewText: Love, love, love this game! This game has an exuberant amount of life skills, providing plenty of hours of entertainment. Life skills range from the standard mining/weapon crafting to cooking and music composition. I personally enjoy any game that allows for a lot of gathering of needed materials and this game surely provides. The fighting system is very involved, so don't expect a point a click. Defense is key to making it through dungeons. They are constantly updating their jobs and quests. The best part is the rebirth system. This allows you to start from lvl 1 while still retaining previous skill levels and an overall level as well as being able to change jobs. One week your a cook, the next a gunslinger. Out of all the free mmos I've played, this one definitely allows for greater amount of freedom than others. The quest and storylines are creative and unique. My only complaint (and it's huge), is that any tume there is an update I am suddenly unable to play the game. I can uninstall and reinstall the game but it doesn't seem to help. I have to wait (usually up to months later) to play the game. This has been happening to me for years; even before the game came to Steam and I have yet to still resolve the problem. Sadly though, the game is just too good for me to stay away permenantly.
